facts.text: The appellant is a medical doctor and at the material time, he was the Civil Surgeon of Dibrugarh.

anchor.surface_text: Sarkar, J. The appellant is a medical doctor and at the material time, he was the Civil Surgeon of Dibrugarh.

facts.text: The appellant was a witness in G. P. Case No. 654/54.

anchor.surface_text: He was a witness in a criminal case being G. P. Case No. 654/54 in which three persons were charged inter alia under s. 376 of the Indian Penal Code with the offence of rape.

facts.text: Three persons were charged inter alia under s. 376 of the Indian Penal Code with the offence of rape in G. P. Case No. 654/54.

anchor.surface_text: in a criminal case being G. P. Case No. 654/54 in which three persons were charged inter alia under s. 376 of the Indian Penal Code with the offence of rape.

facts.text: The case was tried with the aid of a jury and resulted in a verdict of acquittal in respect of that charge.

anchor.surface_text: The case was tried with the aid of a jury and resulted in a verdict of acquittal in respect of that charge.

facts.text: There was an appeal to the High Court of Assam against the acquittal which was allowed and two of the accused persons were convicted.

anchor.surface_text: There was an appeal to the High Court of Assam against the acquittal which was allowed and two of the accused persons were companyvicted.

facts.text: The offence was said to have been committed on a minor girl named Roheswari Chetia sometime in the afternoon of March 19, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The offence was said to have been companymitted on a minor girl named Roheswari Chetia sometime in the afternoon of March 19, 1954.

facts.text: On March 19, 1954 at 6 p.m., Roheswari Chetia was examined by Dr. Dhanbir Pait, the doctor in charge of Moran Dispensary, near which the offence was alleged to have been committed.

anchor.surface_text: The same day at 6 p.m., she was examined by Dr. Dhanbir Pait, the doctor in charge of Moran Dispensary, near which the offence was alleged to have been companymitted.

facts.text: The police produced Roheswari Chetia for another medical examination at Dibrugarh the next day and she was examined by Dr. Mahibulla, assistant to the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the police produced her for another medical examination at the District town of Dibrugarh the next day and she was then examined by Dr. Mahibulla who was an assistant to the appellant, the Civil Surgeon.

facts.text: On March 21, 1954, the police produced the girl before the appellant for a further medical examination and she was examined by him on that date.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the policy on March 21, 1954, produced the girl before the appellant for a further medical examination and she was examined by him on that date.

facts.text: Dr. Pait was called as prosecution witness.

anchor.surface_text: Doctor Pait was called as prosecution witness at the hearing of the case while the appellant and Dr. Mahibulla were called by the accused as defence witnesses.

facts.text: The appellant and Dr. Mahibulla were called by the accused as defence witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: Doctor Pait was called as prosecution witness at the hearing of the case while the appellant and Dr. Mahibulla were called by the accused as defence witnesses.

facts.text: Dr. Pait's evidence: the girl had been raped, found two circular teeth marks on her cheeks, reddish circular mark on left breast, hymen ruptured the same day.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Pait in his evidence was clear that the girl had been raped. He said that he found two circular teeth marks on her cheeks and a reddish circular mark on her left breast. He also said that he found the hymen ruptured and gave other details in support of his opinion that girl had been ravished. In his opinion, the hymen appeared to have been ruptured the same day that he examined the girl.

facts.text: Dr. Mahibulla's evidence: hymen ruptured but nine or ten days before the incident, not recent.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Mahibullas evidence was that the hymen was ruptured but the rupture had taken place nine or ten days before the incident and was number a recent one.

facts.text: Appellant's evidence: marks on cheeks appeared to be insect bites, hymen not ruptured, no evidence of rape.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant in his evidence stated that the marks on the cheeks of the girl appeared to be insect bite and that hymen was number ruptured. He found numberevidence of rape on her person.

facts.text: Direct contradiction between prosecution doctor and defence doctors on rupture of hymen.

anchor.surface_text: There was thus direct companytradiction between the evidence of the doctor called by the prosecution and the doctors called by the defence, on the question of the rupture of the hymen.

facts.text: High Court allowed appeal against acquittal, convicted two accused, based on prosecution doctor's evidence and other evidence.

anchor.surface_text: As we have earlier stated, the High Court allowed the appeal against acquittal in the view that the companymission of the offence of rape had been established by the evidence of the doctor called by the prosecution and other evidence led by it.

facts.text: Appeal to High Court heard by Sarjoo Prosad, C.J., and Deka, J.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal to the High Court was heard by Sarjoo Prosad, C.J., and Deka, J.

facts.text: On 31-7-1958, Sarjoo Prosad C.J. and Deka J. passed order directing issue of notice to Dr. B. K. Pal Chaudhury, D.W. 2, Retired Civil Surgeon, Dibrugarh to show cause why prosecuted under s.193 IPC for false evidence.

anchor.surface_text: After allowing the appeal and companyvicting the two accused, these learned Judges on the same day, passed on order in the terms set out below, directing the issue of a numberice to the appellant. 5. 31-7-1958. Issue numberice on Dr. B. K. Pal Chaudhury  D.W. 2 , Retired Civil Surgeon, Dibrugarh to show cause why he should number be prosecuted under s. 193 I.P.C. for giving false evidence in companynection with G.P. Case No. 654/54,  Lakhimpur, Case No. 72 of 1955  - The State v. Mahendra Nath Barua and Others.

facts.text: The notice was issued and served on the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The numberice was thereafter duly issued and served on the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant showed cause pursuant to the notice.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to the numberice the appellant showed cause,

facts.text: The matter was heard by Deka and Mehrotra JJ.

anchor.surface_text: but this time the matter was heard by Deka and Mahrotra JJ.

facts.text: Deka and Mehrotra JJ. concluded it was a fit case for complaint under s.193 IPC and directed Registrar of High Court to lodge complaint in Court of Deputy Commissioner, Lakhimpur.

anchor.surface_text: These learned Judges came to the companyclusion that it was a fit case in which a companyplaint should be made against the appellant for an offence punishable under s. 193 of the Indian Penal Code and directed and Registrar of the High Court to lodge the companypliant in the Court of the Deputy Commissioner, Lakhimpur.

facts.text: Present appeal filed against the High Court order directing the complaint.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this order directing the making of the companypliant, that the present appeal was filed.

facts.text: High Court did not record a finding that appellant intentionally gave false evidence or that it was expedient to prosecute him.

anchor.surface_text: First there was numberfinding recorded by it that the appellant had intentionally given any false evidence or that it was expedient to proceed against him for the eradication of the evils of perjury and in the interest of justice.

facts.text: High Court did not give appellant proper opportunity of being heard under s.479A(5).

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, it does number seem to us that the High Court gave the appellant a proper hearing to which he was clearly entitled under the terms of sub-section  5  of s. 479A.

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside the High Court order for breach of s.479A(1) and (5).

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore satisfied that order appealed against had been made in breach of the express provisions of sub-secs.  1  and  5  of s. 479A, and cannot be allowed to stand.

concepts.unlisted_description: Prosecution for intentionally giving false evidence by court

anchor.surface_text: S. 479A 6  - No proceedings shall be taken under sections 476 to 479 inclusive for the prosecution of a person for giving or fabricating false evidence, if in respect of such a person proceedings may be taken under this section.

concepts.interpretation: Makes ss.476-479 inapplicable where s.479A applies

concepts.unlisted_description: Exclusion of other sections for false evidence prosecution

anchor.surface_text: Section 479A 1 , so far as it is material to the present case, is in these terms When any . . . Criminal Court is of opinion that any person appearing before it as a witness has intentionally given false evidence in any stage of the judicial proceedings . . . and that, for the eradication of the evils of perjury . . . and in the interests of justice, it is expedient that such witness should be prosecuted for the offence which appears to have been committed by him, the Court shall, at the time of the delivery of the judgment or final order disposing of such proceeding, record a finding to that effect stating its reason therefore and may, if it so thinks fit, after giving the witness an opportunity of being heard, make a complaint thereof.

concepts.interpretation: Requires court to record finding of intentional false evidence and expediency in interests of justice before complaint; must give opportunity of being heard

concepts.unlisted_description: Procedure for court to make complaint for perjury

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section  5  of this section runs as follows In any case, where an appeal has been preferred from any decision of a Civil, Revenue or Criminal Court but no complaint has been made under sub-section  1 , the power conferred on such Civil, Revenue or Criminal Court under the said sub-section may be exercised by the Appellate Court and where the Appellate Court makes such complaint, the provisions of sub-section  1  shall apply accordingly, but no such order shall be made, without giving the person affected thereby an opportunity of being heard.

concepts.interpretation: Appellate court must give opportunity of being heard before making complaint under s.479A(1)

issues.text: Whether the High Court recorded a finding at the time of delivery of judgment or final order that the appellant intentionally gave false evidence and that it was expedient in the interests of justice to prosecute him under s.193 IPC, as required by s.479A(1) CrPC

anchor.surface_text: First there was numberfinding recorded by it that the appellant had intentionally given any false evidence or that it was expedient to proceed against him for the eradication of the evils of perjury and in the interest of justice. The order which directed the numberice to issue - and that seems to be the only order in companynection with the matter - does number record any such finding. Nor do we find in the judgment in the main appeal heard by the High Court in the case in which the appellant gave evidence, any such finding.

issues.text: Whether the High Court gave the appellant a proper opportunity of being heard before making the complaint under s.479A(5) CrPC

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, it does number seem to us that the High Court gave the appellant a proper hearing to which he was clearly entitled under the terms of sub-section  5  of s. 479A. Deka, J., in the judgment that he delivered, directing the companyplaint to be made, companytended himself by saying that the procedure laid down by s. 479A of the Criminal Procedure Code had been substantially followed except that in order to avoid prejudice to the appellant at the trial to follow the companypliant, the reasons for supposing the witness to have perjured had number been elaborately or specifically dealt with.

issues.text: Whether the finding recorded under s.479A(1) CrPC is only prima facie in nature and does not bind the trial court

anchor.surface_text: The finding required to be made by s. 479A 1  is only of a prima facie nature it cannot be a finding which would have any force at the trial upon the companypliant made pursuant to that finding. Further, this numberion of avoiding prejudice would number justify a clear breach of the terms of the section.

issues.text: Whether the show-cause notice Bench was bound by any finding of the appeal Bench on intentional giving of false evidence by the witness

anchor.surface_text: Mehrotra, J., dealing with these companytentions said that these are matters which may be taken into companysideration by the Court trying the case but cannot be companysidered by this Court at this stage. Any observation by this Court on merits is likely to prejudice the trial of the case. He observed that s. 479A was inserted with the object of avoiding further inquiry which inquiry was required by s. 476. There are two further observations made by this learned Judge which are of great materiality in the present appeal and we set them out below The witness is in effect challenging the companyrectness of the findings of the Bench hearing an appeal that he intentionally made a false evidence.

holdings.text: The High Court did not record a finding that the appellant had intentionally given false evidence or that it was expedient to proceed against him for the eradication of the evils of perjury and in the interest of justice, as required by s.479A(1).

anchor.surface_text: First there was no finding recorded by it that the appellant had intentionally given any false evidence or that it was expedient to proceed against him for the eradication of the evils of perjury and in the interest of justice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No such finding in the notice order or in the main appeal judgment.

holdings.text: The High Court did not give the appellant a proper opportunity of being heard as required under s.479A(5).

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, it does not seem to us that the High Court gave the appellant a proper hearing to which he was clearly entitled under the terms of sub-section 5 of s. 479A.

holdings.reasoning_summary: The hearing provided was inadequate; lower court justified non-elaboration of reasons to avoid prejudice, but this breached statutory terms.

holdings.text: The finding required under s.479A(1) is only of a prima facie nature and does not bind the trial court.

anchor.surface_text: The finding required to be made by s. 479A 1 is only of a prima facie nature it cannot be a finding which would have any force at the trial upon the complaint

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory language indicates prima facie opinion only, no preclusive effect at trial.

holdings.text: The show-cause notice bench was not bound by any finding of the appeal bench regarding intentional false evidence.

anchor.surface_text: It is obvious from these observations of Mehrotra, J., that he considered himself bound by the findings of the Bench hearing the appeal that the appellant had intentionally given false evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.479A(5) mandates hearing allowing the court to independently assess and decide not to complain; no prior binding finding existed anyway.

holdings.text: The High Court order directing complaint is set aside as made in breach of s.479A sub-sections (1) and (5).

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore satisfied that order appealed against had been made in breach of the express provisions of sub-secs. 1 and 5 of s. 479A, and cannot be allowed to stand.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative non-compliance with mandatory procedural requirements invalidates the order.

holdings.text: Sub-section (6) of s.479A renders ss.476 to 479 inapplicable where s.479A proceedings may be taken.

anchor.surface_text: the learned Advocates, appearing for the parties to this appeal, agreed that sub-section 6 of s. 479A makes ss. 476 to 479 inapplicable to it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreed by parties; thus unnecessary to consider prior sections.

holdings.text: The combined effect of s.479A(1) and (5) requires recording a finding of intentional false evidence and expediency, and affording opportunity of hearing before complaint.

anchor.surface_text: The combined effect of these sub-sections is to require the court intending to make a complaint, to record a finding that in its opinion a person appearing as a witness has intentionally given false evidence

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of sub-sections mandates both finding and hearing.

holdings.text: Supreme Court declines to make complaint itself under s.479A.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence not fully before court; not appropriate.

holdings.text: Supreme Court declines to remand to High Court for fresh hearing.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Sufficient to set aside invalid order; further action for High Court.
